TextEquiv.Unicode: sight, and at thy right hand is gladnes,
for ever.
What else is this than if hee had
saide, Thou shalt bring me into life,
I say into the verie heavens, where
I shalbe silled with ioyes, both by see
ing and beholding thee, and also by
emoying thee. At thy right hand in e
ternall blessednsse are ioyes everla
sting. In the Gospell also wee reade,
that the Sheepe are placed by the
Iudge at the right hand , and the
Goats at the lest. And when the right
hand is taken in this sense, then To
fitte dooth signifie to rest from all la
bours, and to live quietly ad in hap
pie state. For that saying in the Pro
phet is verie well knowne: A man
shall sitte under his wine. As if hee
should have said all thinges shall be at
peace, in safetie, and at quiet. So then
this that I have said, is meant by the
right hand of the father: and where
we confesse, that the sonne doth sitte
at the right hand of the father almigh
tie, we doe acknowledge, that our
Lorde being delivered from all trou
ble and mortall infirmities, doth now
in his humanitie, both rest and re
ioice in the verie locall place of hea
ven, where we beleeve, that both our
foules and bodies shall be, and live for
ever.
For the Lord himelfe in the Gos
pell witnesseth, that in his fathers
house there are many mansions, which
he goeth to prepare, that they may
have a place, and although hee did de
part, yet that he woulde returne to
them againe, and take them unto him
selfe, that where he is, they also might
be in the same place with him.
Wherefore we beleeve, that Christ is
at rest in Heaven where he hath pre
pared a place of rest for us also, to re
maine in ioies everlasting. And for

sight, and at thy right hand is gladnes, for ever. What else is this than if hee had saide, Thou shalt bring me into life, I say into the verie heavens, where I shalbe silled with ioyes, both by see ing and beholding thee, and also by emoying thee. At thy right hand in e ternall blessednsse are ioyes everla sting. In the Gospell also wee reade, that the Sheepe are placed by the Iudge at the right hand , and the Goats at the lest. And when the right hand is taken in this sense, then To fitte dooth signifie to rest from all la bours, and to live quietly ad in hap pie state. For that saying in the Pro phet is verie well knowne: A man shall sitte under his wine. As if hee should have said all thinges shall be at peace, in safetie, and at quiet. So then this that I have said, is meant by the right hand of the father: and where we confesse, that the sonne doth sitte at the right hand of the father almigh tie, we doe acknowledge, that our Lorde being delivered from all trou ble and mortall infirmities, doth now in his humanitie, both rest and re ioice in the verie locall place of hea ven, where we beleeve, that both our foules and bodies shall be, and live for ever. For the Lord himelfe in the Gos pell witnesseth, that in his fathers house there are many mansions, which he goeth to prepare, that they may have a place, and although hee did de part, yet that he woulde returne to them againe, and take them unto him selfe, that where he is, they also might be in the same place with him. Wherefore we beleeve, that Christ is at rest in Heaven where he hath pre pared a place of rest for us also, to re maine in ioies everlasting. And for
because our bodies shall not be everie
where in felicitie, but in the onelie
appointed place, therefore said saint
Augustine truly, that Christ our Lord
according to the mealure of his verie
bodie is in some one place of heaven.
And saint Cyprian saith: To sit at the
right hand of the father is the myste
rie of his fleshe taken uppe into Hea
ven.
Secondarilie the right hand of God c
is put for the vertue, kingdome, pro
tection, deliveraunce and polver of
God. For David saith: The Lordes
right hand is hight, the Lordes right
hand doth mightie thinges. And Mo
ses saide, Thy right hand GOLorde)
is mgnified in polver, thy right hand
OLord)hath broken the enemie And
when the right hand is put in this
sense, then To sit doth signifie to raign,
to deliver, to use polver, and do the of
fice of a Prince.
For, saith David: The Lorde saide
into my Lorde, sit thou at my right
hand, till I make thine enemes thy
footestoole. And the Prophet Za
charie saith. Beholde the man, that
is called the braunch, he shall budde
out of his place, and builde the Temple
of the Lorde, and sitte and rule upon
his throne, and be a Priost uppon his
seare. In this sense the right hand of
God is infinite and contained in no
measure of place : whereas wee con
fesse, that our Lorde doeth sitte at the
right hand of the father, wee doe pro
fesse, that the sonne is eralted above
all thinges, having all things subiect
under him selfe, as Paule in his
first chapter to the Ephesians saith:
and finally, that the sonne being so
exalted can doe all things, doth raigne
in the universall Church doth deli
ver them that are his, doth make
intercession to the father in Heaven,

because our bodies shall not be everie where in felicitie, but in the onelie appointed place, therefore said saint Augustine truly, that Christ our Lord according to the mealure of his verie bodie is in some one place of heaven. And saint Cyprian saith: To sit at the right hand of the father is the myste rie of his fleshe taken uppe into Hea ven. Secondarilie the right hand of God c is put for the vertue, kingdome, pro tection, deliveraunce and polver of God. For David saith: The Lordes right hand is hight, the Lordes right hand doth mightie thinges. And Mo ses saide, Thy right hand GOLorde) is mgnified in polver, thy right hand OLord)hath broken the enemie And when the right hand is put in this sense, then To sit doth signifie to raign, to deliver, to use polver, and do the of fice of a Prince. For, saith David: The Lorde saide into my Lorde, sit thou at my right hand, till I make thine enemes thy footestoole. And the Prophet Za charie saith. Beholde the man, that is called the braunch, he shall budde out of his place, and builde the Temple of the Lorde, and sitte and rule upon his throne, and be a Priost uppon his seare. In this sense the right hand of God is infinite and contained in no measure of place : whereas wee con fesse, that our Lorde doeth sitte at the right hand of the father, wee doe pro fesse, that the sonne is eralted above all thinges, having all things subiect under him selfe, as Paule in his first chapter to the Ephesians saith: and finally, that the sonne being so exalted can doe all things, doth raigne in the universall Church doth deli ver them that are his, doth make intercession to the father in Heaven,
